job_title: Senior Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Kennedy Krieger is a phenomenal place to work. The people and environment are unparalleled and the benefits are great. Free parking, excellent health insurance, 3 weeks vacation, ample sick days, annual raises, and a bunch of other benefits like a live where you work program, laptop reimbursement, and free collegiate level courses.
cons: Because of its nonprofit status, pay is on the lower end and bonuses are not given.

pros:
Lots of trauma informed experience with special needs
Amazing benefits
cons: It is Understaffed and underpaid

pros:
-Tuition Riembursement is very helpful for anyone in college or graduate school, or seeking a certificate.
-You will get lots of experience with the intellectual and developmental disability population.
-There is some opportunity for growth within KKI.
cons:
-You will spend all your time with the students - no breaks for lunch or stepping away, unless you ask another staff member to cover your student/students for you.
-The pay is not consummerate with the work being asked of you in any way.
-KKI has campaigned extremely hard against unionization - when a group of educators attempted to push forward a vote for a union - KKI employed expensive lawyers and sent letters to all employees provoking fear and suspicion about unions.
-The work is often physically taxing and emotionally exhausting. Many students have high intensity behaviors that necessitate frequent intervention.
-There is high turnover in staff, especially in program aides/classroom assistants, because their pay is so low and they usually are not given adequate training.
-Because of the high turnover, classrooms will often be down staff - which creates a huge burden on the existing staff, and also leads to a lower quality of instruction for the students.

review_title: Overall satisfied, but there's lots of space to improve!
pros: Kennedy Krieger has a lot of great benefits such as a 401k (KKI will match up to 3% of your salary here), paid tuition, and reduced tuition (50% if I remember correctly) for your children.  Health benefits, sick leave, and vacation seem to be very reasonable.  I work in a position where hours are flexible.  The staff is incredibly helpful and pleasant to work with.  There is a 'pay it forward' mentality with respect to training.
cons: The pay is considerably lower than what you'd expect from a government or private industry position.  If funding runs dry, expect to see people let go until more prospects arise.  Your work experience will entirely depend on your supervisor.   I have witnessed quite a bit of favoritism that's based on personal rather than professional relationships.  My experience with respect to supervisors has been less than pleasant - very unprofessional and immature, especially when comparing to such great staff. Being a hospital and research facility, expect to work weekends and holidays if needed.

review_title: Great place to work, but only if you plan making it a career
job_title: Program Aide I in Baltimore, MD
pros: It is by far the most friendly and supportive environment I've worked in. I worked at the K-8 school for students with special needs as a Program Aide I. Good hours (7:30 - 2:30), free parking and transportation (shuttle), friendly supervisors and management. I loved the kids and classroom I worked in. Co-workers were amazing. Just a great environment if you can handle kids with special needs.
cons: As a Program Aide, $12/hr is very low. The teachers and assistants have a lot between designing lessons, paperwork, meetings, and individualized education plans, but are compensated. As a Program Aide, you work one on one with students, helping them with work, social issues, and physically transporting them to a resource area if they become a threat to themselves or others (along with accompanying paperwork). That's all fine and good but $12/hr for one of the most hands on jobs at the school is low. Raises are also capped.

pros: The clinical research department has the opportunity to be a fantastic resource to families who come to Kennedy Krieger Institute for care
cons: The clinical research unit has a very high turnover rate, with employees leaving after 8 weeks. The veterans or employees who have stayed longer in the unit practice favoritism and are more focused on the power struggle/politics instead of helping the patients coming in. There have also been situations where other new staff members have been bullied and prejudice based on national origin and appearance have been evident. All issues have been  brought to the attention of management and human resources department with no solution. This leaves employees who come in with a true dedication and commitment to the work, with the feeling that they are not appreciated and management is more focused on profit making instead of investing in employees

review_title: It is an experience like none other.
job_title: Special Education Teacher in Baltimore, MD
pros: This place is somewhere that I am proud to say that I work. Awesome environment, great experience for future jobs, wonderful co workers, positive place. I love what I do. I love the fact that I am helping out an environment that so many people choose to either neglect or walk all over. I love being an advocate for my kids.
cons: I am here for the benefits of tuition reimbursement and the experience.  It is somewhere that I love, but would love more if I got paid what I was worth. I know SO MANY people that are making at LEAST 10 thousand more than me a year, doing the same thing, if not less than what I do.Severely underpaid,  and sometimes I hate the "politics" of the job.

job_title: Clinical Assistant I in Baltimore, MD
pros: Very hard work and out of this world experiences, people will not be able to relate to you or understand the work you do and that's what makes this job so special. Because you're doing one of a kind work and helping children and others with autism and behavioral disorders that are extreme cases from around the world.
cons: Hard work. Be humble. Prepare to be a father or mother in training, you'll be picking up and cleaning your patient, and more likely yourself of your patient's pee, vomit, poop, and God knows what else. If something like this can turn you off, don't bother. It is an acquired skill to tolerate all these and definitely possible. Very stressful at the beginning but you get used to it, and stress goes down after 3 months.

review_title: Could be worse like being unemployed.
job_title: Healthcare Administration Professional in Baltimore, MD
pros: A great place to build working relationships. Benefits are okay and tuition reimbursement is great. The company is great with its patients, families and community.
cons: Sometimes hard work, skills and dedication is not enough because unless you know someone it is very difficult to move around within the company. After years of merit increases it is difficult for a veteran employee to transfer to a different department because the position starting pay is lower than the employees current salary. There is a lot of nepotism,,,that is all I am saying on that.

pros:
meet interesting people
great benefits after 6 months
cons:
no consideration from upper management to staff- one of the students had a fungal rash and when the teacher told the principal- she waved away the concern and EVERY staff member in the classroom was infected with it. 
Students attacked staff members frequently and no one cares or seeks to work on safety plans
extreme strick adherance to protocol - even if it ends up being harmful- such as doing PCM repeatedly even when it's clearly not workng anymore 
No sense of rules and safety for staff- A staff member became furious and started yelling at me for no reason. She grabbed my shoulders and shook me and when I reported this to HR they did nothing. I quit shortly thereafter and the principal snatched the tag and dismissed me without even inquiring why I was leaving.
The pay is extremely low also
no opportunity to move forward

pros: Only the medical care is good, but even then there are other places to go - they are not the only game in town.
cons: Senior Managements believes that it's okay to belittle woman, make sexual comments about women to name a few. There is no reason that a VP should stand and gawk at a woman employee who works for him and say how much he "enjoys casual Fridays." Note - she had a good figure and looked great in jeans. Another VP was heard speaking to a woman in a patronizing voice. or condescending way "don't worry your pretty little head about it." That type of behavior by anyone but in particular leadership is totally unacceptable in this day and age. But it is a good ole boys network there and if you buck them, you are labeled as not a team player.

review_title: Not too bad, but could be better.
pros: Kennedy Krieger is committed to its patients and students. The Institute always has the latest and best therapies, teaching methods, and technologies. Kennedy also offers good benefits to its employees.
cons: Kennedy is less concerned with employee satisfaction and well-being. It is not uncommon for staff to feel over-stretched and unsupported from administration. There are high turn-over rates for paraprofessionals and teaching staff because of this.

pros: Best working support and atmosphere I've seen, When there was an issue, management was quick to correct it. Open to ideas and suggestions to improve care and the unit itself. A very fulfilling job since you get to see how the patients improve over time.
cons: Work itself is very high stress and pay was minimal, so there was a very high turnover.

pros:
- Your work directly helps the future treatment methods for patients, as most investigators are physicians as well.
- Many of the technicians are willing to teach other lab groups how to do certain tests or techniques they are familiar with.
- A great place to pick up a lot of laboratory-based skills.
cons:
- Mostly entry level positions with very little prospect for advancement.
- Research is heavily dependent upon grants and donations, which is typical of an academic setting.
- Some investigators are difficult to work with and there are a lot of impediments when it comes to getting work done, either due to old tech or limitations on usage time of certain devices or work spaces.

pros: Interesting work with smart people. State-of-the-art equipment and labs. You are part of the Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, which is number one in the world, or should be!
cons: Not a very safe area of Baltimore, so parking and housing can be difficul, but there is a metro station right under the campus, so you can live some distance away. The pay is not at the top, but you are working at Johns Hopkins, your resume will forever shine!

review_title: Center for Autism and Related Disorders (CARD) (REACH Lab)
pros:
- Colleagues care about the research participants
- Civil work environment
- Work-life balance
- Continuing education opportunities
-Friendly workplace
cons:
- Upper management (and some mid-managers) fail to recognize the expertise of the staff and ignore anyone without a PhD
- High turnover because of a lack of respect and opportunities to advance
- Tough and repetitive work that does not challenge or engage

review_title: Great place to work but pay is low
pros:
-Health care package was great for myself, husband and son
-They have tuition assistance 
-My supervisor was great and provided constructive feedback
-Co-workers were all invested in the job
-I loved working with the clients 
-Lots of support and education regarding the field
cons: -Pay was low. It was appropriate for entry-level staff but there was no way to make more money (as a TA) once experience was gained. I would still be employed there if there was a way to make more money as a TA.

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Decent company benefits and opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration.
cons: The Speech-Language Department at the Broadway location is a negative, hostile environment with foundations of mistrust, control, and micromanagement. To summarize, empty promises, inefficient documentation, low pay, unfair treatment across team members, and lack of work life balance and respect result in high turn over both within the SLP team and office staff. All issues have been brought to HR several times, with no changes to date. For anybody considering employment within this department, both CF and CCC- SLPs, do yourself a favor and look elsewhere.

review_title: Since I have a Psych degree the one-to-one care, and treatments I learned were worth it. I worked there for 3yrs.
job_title: Clinical Assistant I in Baltimore, MD
pros:
-You meet great people that will most likely become life-long friends.
-If your into human behavior this is definitely a perfect place to gain experience with harder disorders.
-A great place to move up in your career. (The overall hospital not the Neurobehavioral Unit).
-Tuition reimbursement after 6 months.
cons:
-Time off is difficult depending on staffing.
- FT you have to work all weekends. PT you have to work 1 weekend day most likely an eve shift.
-No union due to the hospital being Non-profit, meaning your job is not secure and a rumor may get your fired so be careful.
-Expect to be injured, and they will not compensate you until your 4th day out of work.
-Turn over rate is high due to injury, and severity of how dangerous the job can be.
-The recruiter looks for former graduates and college students because school is reimbursed, however you may not receive this reimbursement until after 6 months and during the interview you are told that you probably wont make it to six months because the turn-over rate is so high.
-Employee appreciation rarely exists, so expect long hours, mandatory overtime, lots of on-calls, no weekends off, no holidays off, sometimes you will not have a break, and write-ups are very common.
-Supervisors can be unreliable, childish, and treat employees as if they are children despite the knowledge or work ethic.
-While training on the unit current employees are told to hide the truth behind the job as a means to not scare prospective employees off.
-Almost every employee hates the job and expresses it while working.
-For the amount of work and hours, the pay is just a touch over minimum wage. (And this includes the raises that were given in 2014)
-When asking a supervisor a question expect to be redirected multiple times because no one ever knows the solution.

review_title: Wonderful Opportunity for Professional Development, Although Not Long-Term
job_title: Clinical Assistant I in Baltimore, MD
pros:
I worked on the Neurobehavioral Unit (NBU) for almost two years. 

- Wonderful benefits (401k immediately after hire, tuition reimbursement, computer payment plan, health care, and all the bells and whistles).
- Great opportunity to work in the field of psychology, autism, and applied behavior analysis.
- Although hard work, seeing the patients from day one to the day of discharge can be very rewarding.
- They are willing to work with you on your schedule, especially if you're a student (majority of the NBU are undergrad or grad students). You will be working evening shift for a while but, however, you'll be able to get onto day shift in no time, even as a part-timer. Just fill out the paper work and follow up.
- The Program Specialists were always helpful and very supportive, especially if you've always been honest with them. (i.e., calling out, opportunities for growth, issues such as bereavement). 
- You are guaranteed an hour-long break.
- Promotions open up often, which provides opportunities for growth for all employees. 
- You can shadow a therapist for a day shift. REALLY great opportunity in getting to know the behavior team and see what they do.
cons:
- KKI's policy on providing references is that it ONLY applies to KKI itself or for a college/university limits professional recommendations to outside companies.
- Little staff appreciation. CA of the Month award always goes to the same 10 people each month and the fried chicken buffet every August means little.
- Coworkers hate the job and openly complain about it throughout your shift.
- Write ups occur often, especially over frivolous things. A rumor can get your fired. 
- Neoptism from management and therapist teams tend to reward underqualified and/or incompetent employees.
- High intensity environment of the NBU leads to high turn over rates. People have even walked out on the job during shifts.
- No negotiation for the already low salary. I was offered CA III for $12.85 an hour compared to my new job that pays significantly more and less than 10 minutes away from me. 
- Inflexibility of schedule logisitics. For instance, you're required to sign up for a certain amount of on-calls every six weeks, full-time must work Saturday and Sunday unless promoted, and part-time were required to work at least one weekend shift. Turning down on-calls and mandatory overtime result in automatic write-ups.

pros: Lab Director provided reasonable expectations, permitted me autonomy, and great support.  Any issue I brought up was handled immediately.
cons: There was very little room for growth. Worked for three years with no increase.  When working in soft money (grant-funded) when your Lab Director leaves, you either have to move with the job or find another position.

job_title: Clinical Assistant I in Baltimore, MD
pros: Patients are very interesting to work with. Very rewarding experience if you have the patience for it.
cons: I got beat up. Its an extremely dangerous job. They don't pay you well at all for the amount of work you do. They are not flexible with the scheduling. You get paid 12 bucks an hour to get beat up by the children. I got punched and bitten on my first day of training.  I couldn't even make it through training.

job_title: Program Aide & Therapeutic Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: very rewarding if you like the population you're working with, very up-to-date on current research and evidence-based practices, sites that receive more funding (like CARD) treat their employees very well, good benefits. My rating to recommend to a friend is with conditions (depends on which position they would be applying for)
cons: depending on the site/ the funding, the direct-care-workers (aides) do not get treated as well as employees in "higher" positions, low pay

review_title: Good place for learning and building connections
pros: A good place to build relationships with some very smart people. Excellent resources in the form of classes/libraries/study groups through Johns Hopkins University.
cons: Being a small Institute it is very hierarchial with alot of inside politics. Difficult to have any form of career growth. In research labs, your experience depends entirely on your PI as he/she defines the lab ethics & environment.

pros: Gained valuable experiences working with the ASD population. Everyone there  is truly there to make significant contributions to the field and that is clear from the environment.
cons: Benefits and salaries are on the low end for the hours expected from their employees. Would be nice to have more significant packages that are competitive with other areas of the market.

pros:
meet interesting people 
great benefits after 6 months
cons:
upper management has no consideration for staff's physical/ emotional safety or wellbeing. examples: a student had a fungal infection and when the teacher told the principal, the principal waved off the concern, and EVERY staff member in the classroom got the infection. 
Poor teamwork amongst staff. example: a staff member got furious at me for no reason and started yelling at me. she grabbed my shoulders and shook me and when i reported it to HR they did nothing. I quit shortly thereafter the the principal just snatched my tag and dismissed me without even asking why i was leaving.

pros: Kennedy Krieger Institute is a great learning experience. The employees here are caring and intelligent people who you enjoy working with. They put patient's best interest at heart. Health benefits are great, and there is free parking!
cons: Low compensation. Depending what your job is, there may be a high turn over rate due to the nature of the job (understandably). May have politics within the department you work for, but that may be true in most work places.

review_title: Inspiring work, great culture & benefits, brilliant colleagues
pros: really great place to work!  I absolutely love the people I work with.  Very caring and so bright.  Everyday is a learning experience and I feel as if I am truly making a difference in the lives of so many kids.  Culture is inspiring but relaxed, awesome benefits and really great professional development opportunities and tuition.  Fun place to work!
cons: I don't have any at this time.

job_title: Clinical Assistant I in Baltimore, MD
pros: Meaningful work, good culture and management was overall very nice and helpful.
cons: Working in the NBU can be tough, the patients are some of the most intense...CAs are underpaid, work schedules are predetermined and inflexible with the exception that they will work around any classes you are taking.

review_title: Slow to adapt to changing times
job_title: Instructional Media Developer in Baltimore, MD
pros: Large network, great schools and patient care. Facilities are tremendous.
cons: Slow to adapt to technology, It takes a long time to get much accomplished there. Many of the decisions have to go though Medical staff and the Medical staff doesn't always offer the best leadership.

review_title: Big Potential but little follow thru
pros: helping children and families who struggle with rare disabilities and diseases, benefits, connection to Johns Hopkins Hospital. Good work life balance
cons: Dysfunctional organization, Upper-Management in denial about needed change, good ole boys club among upper-management, promotion comes based on number of years instead of most qualified. Company itself is resistant to change

review_title: Wide range of opportunities for employment
pros: Kennedy has a job in almost every field of the professional world, and you will learn a lot no matter what department you're in.
cons: Unfortunately there seems to be a lot of favoritism in place in many departments and you may not get the compensation you deserve.

review_title: Experience at KKI has been the best, beside management.
job_title: Care Center Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: The benefits that KKI has is the best. The tutition reimbursement and health benefits, the flexible hours that they offer.
cons: I don't like the management of KKI. It's horrible and the unfair treatment that some employees receive. Supervisor need more training.

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great benefits! The tuition benefit and live near your work program are great incentives!
cons: Not a lot of room for growth depending on what department you work for but is a great place to gain experience.  Needs more training and professional development programs for mid-line managers and lower level employees.

review_title: DO. NOT. WORK. HERE. ESPECIALLY NEW CLINICIANS.
job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good health insurance options, free parking
cons:
SLPs and Clinical Fellows-- Do NOT work at the Broadway Location (outpatient, feeding, BI, or NBU). I know that KKI is a good "resume builder" for some people (that's why I decided to work here), but I can promise you that it's not worth it. Run and don't look back

Management seems charming at first, but they have run the Speech and language department into the ground. They're so fragile and defensive that you will NEVER be able to disagree with them or state an opinion that they don't like.

They always choose one CF to gang up on every year, and it's depressing to watch. They bully at least one into leaving KKI every year. Micromanagement is something everyone deals with all day, every day. As a new hire, every eval you do and every report you write is intensely watched and criticized. The supervisors are extremely nosy and make you CC them on almost every single email. There's someone constantly looking over your shoulder for your first six months AT LEAST>

Aside from when you go from CF to getting your Cs, you won't get another raise or promotion for YEARS, if at all, no matter how hard you work. They will never negotiate salary with you, and they have no interest in having you advance in the organization. You’ll be underpaid, and they won’t care. 

The amount of turnover is shocking. They go through administrative assistants constantly and take forever to replace them. As of this month, the dept. has lost 6 SLPs in less than 18 months. They take forever to replace SLPs too- prepare to cover both your workload AND the workload of the person who leaves when this happens, because the supervisors won’t help at all. Management is completely unwilling to accept feedback and change-- they just make the other staff do all of that work on their own personal time. 

The workload is ridiculous. People stay well past their scheduled hours every single day to finish reports and other responsibilities. Some SLPs even take work home with them to do on the weekends. 

Please, please don't work here. Management will make your life miserable, unless you're a really passive person who doesn't mind being bossed around and you never speak up for yourself. This department is a mess. Also...HR will never care about your concerns. Everyone has tried to warn them about how unhappy the staff is, and they’ve done absolutely nothing. They don't listen AT ALL to what's wrong with the department, though they definitely pretend to. 

I get that you want to work somewhere reputable and well known. I was just like you once. I thought that this place would make a huge difference for my career. Please understand that speech and language isn't like the rest of KKI. You'll be mistreated and it won't get better, regardless of how hard you work or how nice you try to be to management. KKI Speech and Language is a nightmare.

pros: Im sure the culture and diversity in the company is great.
cons: The care management department is the worse Run. The Director and management staff here is a joke.  They have high favoritism in the department so if you not in with the clicks you can forget it.  Not worth the stress and hassle they put you through.

job_title: Care Center Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Room for growth, annual raises. Decent benefits. If you have a supportive manager, there is always room for growing and learning. Training opportunities always available.
cons: Maternity leave not a great package.  Annual raises not based on performance. It can be very challenging to get things done sometimes because there's a policy and procedure in place for absolutely everything.

review_title: Not paid enough for the work (Fairmount)
pros: Nice to help kids, if you can get into a supportive classroom, good learning experience. Opportunity for advancement.
cons: Work is very hard and draining, most classrooms were unsupportive of aides and felt like you were being judged for not doing a good job if you were having trouble handling your students behaviors.

pros: Decent salaries. Good benefits if you research everything and find what works best for you. To utilize the best benefits they make you jump through hoops but most employers do that.  Easy to transfer to other position.
cons: The institute says they are very diverse but that diversity is only applies to certain positions and departments.

job_title: Clinical Assistant I in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great coworkers! Day shift during the week is awesome! Team members are very helpful. It is awesome to see a child progress and their behaviors diminish.
cons: Stressful and tiring. It's takes a special person to work on this unit. You will be wiped out after a few days. Scheduling can be rough as well, especially with on calls!

job_title: Care Center Specialist in Baltimore, MD

KKI is changing lives. It is great to see this right in front of you. 
Great benefits. Decent pay. 
Very involved in community. Nice facilities.
cons: Within my part of the department management is not very good. They micro-manage, are very secretive, and do not give ample feedback or appreciation.

review_title: It is a tremendous opportunity to learn and grow with the best in the industry.

cons: Not paid the best considering the resposiblity you have for taking good care of children on the autism spectrum, but it depends on the position and how strict your manager is also.

cons: Lack of upward mobility in some of the departments leaving employee's stagnant and feeling burned out and over worked.

pros: Great benefits. Enjoyable work-life culture. Great cause to work for.

pros: Working with kids was great! You had the ability to really change some of the lives of the children who needed it most.

pros: Able to trade or give away shifts, health insurance available from first day.
